Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Bioinspired Insight into Gas Transport at the Microscale

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Staples
1437387

The objective of the proposed research is to investigate microfluidic flow of gases inspired by the manner in which insects manage to pump gas through their microscopic breathing air ducts. The project aims to develop a combination of theoretical and computational tools to explore novel microfluidic methods for gas transport. In particular, the PI will capitalize on her group's ongoing research that studies 3D gas transport in arthropods. The research objectives include theoretical methods to obtain reduced order models for flow in inelastic tubes, and computational methods to develop meshfree simulations of the process. Using this simulation approach, one of the objectives of the proposed research is to assess the validity of using an inelastic tube with local contractions in a practical microfluidic-system for gas transport.

Current gas microfluidic devices are mostly 2D geometries and are indistinguishable from liquid microfluidic devices. They generally consist of smooth, straight channels with uniform cross sections, and are in general ineffective. However, this project is focused on exploring exactly this recently discovered paradigm inspired from nature: gas transport in insect respiratory systems relies on inelastic but locally collapsible tracheal tubes, which differs from macroscopic transport or liquid flow across small spaces. This research program can lead to designing novel microfluidic strategies and devices. Poor gas flow distribution capacities severely limit many microfluidics applications important to public health and industry. In addition to the cooling of handheld electronics devices, many artificial tissue growth and medical lab-on-a-chip technologies are currently limited because of ineffective 3D gas distribution at the microscale. The proposed work could potentially have a profound impact in these fields.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to investigate the use of paradigms from nature for building better microfluidic devices. These devices have several important applications, including point-of-care medical diagnostic devices emerging as a promising tool for improving global health. Specifically, in this project, we studied and implemented some of the fundamental features of insect respiration – the only system found in nature in which gas flows occur at the microscale – in a series of novel microfluidic device designs. We also derived associated theoretical models for the flow rate in these devices and carried out computations to predict the flow in the devices.

To begin, we hypothesized that the two unique features of insect respiratory flows that lead to its extraordinary effectiveness are its automaticity and instrinsicality. The automaticity in the system resides in that the respiratory air flow moves in a network of tubes that automatically collapse when the insect contracts its abdomen/makes ordinary motions, and these collapses help drive the tidal respiratory flow in conjunction with an automatic pressure gradient that occurs from oxygen being consumed at the tissues. The intrinsicality of the system resides in its intrinsic geometric features: that the network tubes reach such small diameters near the tissue that the air begins to “slip” against the walls of the tubes as the average distance air molecules travel during random motions becomes comparable to the tube diameters, leading to a reduction in the friction forces that have to be overcome with work.

Using this hypothesis, we derived minimal theoretical models of the insect respiratory actuation mechanism that reproduced the automatic and instrinsic features and predicted the air flow rate as a function of tube wall contraction rate, the contraction amplitude, and the tube geometry. We added slip effects to the model for the smaller respiratory tubes to determine the reduction in friction forces. We performed a series of computations based on the reduced-order model. Then, guided by the results from our models and computations, we designed a series of novel microfluidic devices that included the features of automaticity and intrinsicality.

We found that insect-inspired microfluidic devices designed using the properties of automaticity and intrinsicality require only a third of the power input to drive a flow at the same rate as typical microfluidic device designs.

Four graduate students were educated and trained during the course of the project, with one graduate student and one postdoctoral researcher being directly supported by the project. The results from the research reached hundreds of scientific colleagues via talks given at scientific conferences, workshops, and seminars, and one press conference at the 2018 APS March Meeing on March 6, 2018, and were published in three refereed journals and two refereed conference proceedings. In conjunction with the Science Museum of Southwest Virginia, a K-12 educational unit on insect physics was developed that is used in a series of STEM summer camps for girls from disadvantaged backgrounds.

 


Last Modified: 02/22/2018
Modified by: Anne Staples
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The purpose of this project was to investigate the use of paradigms from nature for building better microfluidic devices. These devices have several important applications, including point-of-care medical diagnostic devices emerging as a promising tool for improving global health. Specifically, in this project, we studied and implemented some of the fundamental features of insect respiration – the only system found in nature in which gas flows occur at the microscale – in a series of novel microfluidic device designs. The automaticity in the system resides in that the respiratory air flow moves in a network of tubes that automatically collapse when the insect contracts its abdomen/makes ordinary motions, and these collapses help drive the tidal respiratory flow in conjunction with an automatic pressure gradient that occurs from oxygen being consumed at the tissues. Then, guided by the results from our models and computations, we designed a series of novel microfluidic devices that included the features of automaticity and intrinsicality.
